newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Bangladesh urged to privatise aggressively.
newsitem.headline: Bangladesh urged to privatise aggressively.

text.p: Bangladesh has suffered nearly $1.86 billion in losses over five years due to inefficient public enterprises and must aggressively privatise, the chief of the Bangladesh Privatisation Board said on Wednesday.

"We have no option but to go for aggressive privatisation. The slow and uneasy process of privatisation has caused a total loss amounting to some 80 billion taka (nearly $1.86 billion) from fiscal 1991-92 to 1995-96 (July-June)," said Kazi Zafarullah.
He told a meeting with leading businessmen that the government had given 420 billion taka ($9.76 bln) in subsidies to state-owned enterprises (SOEs) over the past 21 years.
"The SOEs were also given huge loans, but 90 percent of it, nearly 130 billion taka ($3.02 bln), has not been repaid," Zafarullah said.
"This has resulted in a severe liquidity crisis in the lending banks."

He called the loss-making public enterprises -- which were overstaffed and mismanaged -- a "cancer of the economy" that cost the government 25 billion taka ($580 million) each year, or an equivalent of two percent of gross domestic product.
The World Bank said in a recent report 225 non-financial SOEs under 39 corporations incurred losses equivalent to 27 percent of Bangladesh's annual development programmes.
The privatisation board listed 95 state-owned enterprises in jute, textile, engineering, sugar, food and chemicals sectors that Zafarullah said should be disposed of immediately.
"We could make little progress so far...only one jute mill is now in the final stage of privatisation," Zafarullah said.
The government would sell out its shares in 18 enterprises, said Zafarullah, who took office only a month ago.
"Privatisation is an important element of the government's overall economic adjustment strategy. The process will soon gain momentum," he said.
"The government of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has assigned top priority to the privatisation process in its economic reform programme."
Zafarullah blamed the "dismal condition" of the public sector largely on the failures of the previous government.
Ailing industrial units should have been swiftly transferred to private ownership to prune their management, inject fresh capital and create jobs, he said.
He also said the privatisation programme faced stiff opposition from restive labour unions and political groups, helping to delay the process.
"I am now trying seriously to implement the government's policy in this regard as fast as possible," Zafarullah said.
He said the board had proposed to the government that it would not ask prospective buyers of state-owned enterprises to disclose their source of funding.
"This (proposal) is under consideration," he said, without elaborating.
